course.subject: FINA
course.name: Venture Capital Financing
course.description: This course covers the application of financial tools and techniques to the funding and valuation of an entrepreneurial venture. The course seeks to provide students with a background on the venture capital industry, the economic intuition underlying its features, and the basic tools required to work in the industry.

reviews.author: carpeDiem
reviews.title: Interesting course about venture capital
reviews.comment_content:
1. Venture Capital Industry
2. Startup Valuation
3. Venture Capital Incentives
(Real options, debt overhang, asset substitution...)
4. Contract Valuation
(Value convertible shares, participating convertible preferred shares, and other structures using portfolio replication technique with Black-Scholes; anti-dilution clauses and implied valuation...)
5. Exiting Investments (the IPO process)

For people who had a wonderful time learning about financial derivatives (FINA3203 / MATH4514) or have listened to venture capitalists pitching their VC funds during their internships, this course may be your cup of tea!
reviews.comment_teaching:
- Classes are fairly interactive. Prof. asks many reflective questions in class

- Prof. and the TA are very responsive to emails

- Prof. talks in a concise and succinct manner. He never finishes the classes late

- PPTs are easy to understand (clarify with Prof. if any questions pop up
reviews.comment_grading:
20% Group/individual assignment
(= case*2, you can collaborate with selected classmates in different sessions up to 4ppl/group)
10% Class participation (not entirely based on attendance on Zoom)
20% Midterm exam
50% Final exam

I may be biased because I got an A:
- Assignment 1: 9/10
- Assignment 2: 10/10
- Class participation: not published on Canvas but I was quite active in class discussions
- Midterm: 42.5/50 (mean: 39, stdev: 6)
- Final: not published on Canvas

For the midterm and final exams, remember to manage your time wisely...
Skip the hard questions and revisit them if you have time.
reviews.comment_workload:
- Assigned reading: Read the cases (10+ pages each) before attending lectures to get on the same page with the professor during class discussions

- Assignments: split the work with your team members and arrange meetings with them (our team had 2 meetings for each case)

- Working on practice problems and sample midterm/final questions: they are not for grading purposes but are absolutely helpful in preparing for the midterm and final exams

reviews.author: ft
reviews.comment_content:
4603 = 3103 + 3203 + 3303 + 3403
Topics: corporate finance, DCF, multiples, contract valuation, anti-dilution, implied valuation, exit valuation.
Prerequisite: FINA3403, but he can waive it for you.
I finally know what's going on in 3303 and 3403 after taking this course. Course materials are difficult but notes are full of examples.
Practice problems, sample midterm, sample final are provided. They are very similar to exam questions.
reviews.comment_teaching:
a bit boring...
many typos in the notes (as this is the first time to have this course)
reviews.comment_grading:
10% Parti
20% Cases
20% Midterm
50% Final

or
12.5% Parti
25% Cases
62.5% Final

Count the better one :)
reviews.comment_workload:
only 2 short cases (in group, 2-3 pages are enough)

midterm: 1-page double-side cheat sheet
final: 2-page double-side cheat sheet
